pullRequest.body:
Add various results concerning modules `M / R` and `M' / R'` with maps `i : R -> R'` and `j : M -> M'` which are compatible with scalar multiplications on `M` and `M'`.

- if `i : R' -> R` is injective and `j` is injective, then:
  - `LinearIndependent.map_of_injective_injective`: `j` preserves linear independent subsets.
  - `[lift_]rank_le_of_injective_injective`: rank of `M / R` is smaller than or equal to the rank of `M' / R'`.
- if `i` is surjective and `j` is injective, then:
  - `LinearIndependent.map_of_surjective_injective`: `j` preserves linear independent subsets.
  - `[lift_]rank_le_of_surjective_injective`: rank of `M / R` is smaller than or equal to the rank of `M' / R'`.
- if `i` and `j` are both bijective, then `[lift_]rank_eq_of_equiv_equiv`: rank of `M / R` is equal to the rank of `M' / R'`.

Also add the `Algebra` versions of these results.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

Discussion thread: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/.E2.9C.94.20.60E.2FL.2FF.60.20and.20.60K.2FL'.2FF.60.20isomorphic.20.3D.3E.20.60.5BE.3AL.5D.3D.5BK.3AL'.5D.60/near/408072594

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: 🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by alreadydone.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7298907168/job/19890725298)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7298907168/job/19890724946)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7298907168/job/19890725111)

I know this condition is similar to [SemilinearMapClass](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/LinearMap.html#SemilinearMapClass), but it seems the more morally correct statement is `i : ZeroHom R' R`, `Injective i` and `j (i r' • m) = r' • j m` for `r' : R` and `m : M` in this situation. And it seems strictly more general.
Thanks. Do you have any suggestions on the `[lift]_rank_eq` version? Currently I keep the condition of them unchanged.
The eq versions use bijections so I suppose it doesn't matter which direction they're in?

You can avoid nontrivial/subsingleton case splits by following the proof of `lift_rank_le_of_injective`:
```suggestion
  simp_rw [Module.rank, lift_iSup (bddAbove_range.{v', v'} _), lift_iSup (bddAbove_range.{v, v} _)]
  exact ciSup_mono' (bddAbove_range.{v', v} _) fun ⟨s, li⟩ ↦ ⟨⟨j '' s,
    (li.map_of_injective_injective i j hi (fun x hx ↦ hj <| by rwa [j.map_zero]) hc).image⟩,
      lift_mk_le'.mpr ⟨(Equiv.Set.image j s hj).toEmbedding⟩⟩
```

```suggestion
    rwa [hi', i.map_zero] at h
  rw [hc (i' s) x, hi']
```
same in `map_of_surjective_injective`

```suggestion
    lift.{v'} (Module.rank R M) = lift.{v} (Module.rank R' M') :=
  (lift_rank_le_of_surjective_injective i j hi.surjective j.injective hc).antisymm <|
    lift_rank_le_of_injective_injective i j.symm (fun x hx ↦ hi.1 <| by rwa [i.map_zero])
      j.symm.injective fun s x ↦ j.symm_apply_eq.mpr <| by erw [hc, j.apply_symm_apply]
```

```suggestion
  · rw [← i.map_zero]; apply hi
  have := congr($hc s) -- some elaboration magic ... two more below can be replaced 
  simp only [RingHom.coe_comp, comp_apply] at this
  simp_rw [smul_def, AddMonoidHom.coe_coe, map_mul, this]
```
Stylistic question: why do you give elements of `R'` the name `s`? Isn't `r` still available?
